newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong gold gets fillip from short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong gold gets fillip from short-covering.

text.p: Gold closed higher in Hong Kong on Tuesday, boosted by short-covering as well as some improvement in physical gold demand, dealers and traders said.
Local and overseas traders covered short positions, accounting for the price fillip in mid-afternoon trade, dealers said.
"One fund from the U.S. was particularly active in short-covering," said a bullion trader at an international bank.
Some gold sales from Japanese traders was noted during the morning but was absorbed by professional buying, traders said.
Physical demand also perked up as buyers panicked slightly when gold prices did not drop below $380 after Hong Kong's long weekend as anticipated, dealers said
Monday was a market holiday in Hong Kong.
Traders said they saw gold remaining range-bound between $380-383, with fresh selling expected at around $381.50-382.00, Hong Kong traders said.
Bullion ended at US$382.30-382.80 an ounce on Tuesday against New York's US$381.75/382.25 close on Monday.
Local gold ended HK$23 higher at HK$3,525 a tael.
The carry over charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society rose to -3.00 from its previous fix at -5.40.
